hints_html: Recall that from part (a) that \(\displaystyle A\mathbf x_{\infty} = 4\mathbf x_{\infty}\).
hints_latex:
Recall that from
{part
(a)} that $\displaystyle A\mathbf x_{\infty} = 4\mathbf x_{\infty}$.
hints_raw: Recall that from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_07_(a)|part (a)]] that <math> \displaystyle A\mathbf x_{\infty} = 4\mathbf x_{\infty} </math>.
question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
From part (a), we recall that \(\displaystyle \lambda = 4\) was the eigenvalue associated to the eigenvector \(\displaystyle x_{\infty}\). We can use these to find the solution:

\[\begin{aligned} Ax_{\infty} &= \lambda x_{\infty}\\ Ax_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty} &= \lambda x_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty}\\ Ax_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty} &= 4(1)\\ \langle \mathbf{x}_\infty, A\mathbf{x}_\infty\rangle &= 4\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
From part (a), we recall that $\displaystyle \lambda = 4$ was the
eigenvalue associated to the eigenvector $\displaystyle x_{\infty}$. We
can use these to find the solution:

\begin{align*}
Ax_{\infty} &= \lambda x_{\infty}\\
Ax_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty} &= \lambda x_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty}\\
Ax_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty} &= 4(1)\\
\langle \mathbf{x}_\infty, A\mathbf{x}_\infty\rangle &= 4
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
From part (a), we recall that <math>\displaystyle \lambda = 4 </math> was the eigenvalue associated to the eigenvector <math>\displaystyle x_{\infty} </math>. We can use these to find the solution:

<math>
\begin{align}
Ax_{\infty} &= \lambda x_{\infty}\\
Ax_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty} &= \lambda x_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty}\\
Ax_{\infty}\cdot x_{\infty} &= 4(1)\\
\langle \mathbf{x}_\infty, A\mathbf{x}_\infty\rangle &= 4
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Suppose that A is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1, 4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors \(\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^4\) by choosing x0 at random, and then settings

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\ \mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|\end{aligned}\]

for n = 1, 2, .... You then observe that xn converges to

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T\end{aligned}\]

as \(n \to \infty\).

(b) What is the value of the inner (dot) product \(\langle \mathbf{x}_\infty, A\mathbf{x}_\infty\rangle\)?
statement_latex:
Suppose that \emph{A} is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1,
4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors $\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^4$ by
choosing \textbf{x}\textsubscript{0} at random, and then settings

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\
\mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|
\end{align*}

for \emph{n = 1, 2, ...}. You then observe that
\textbf{x}\textsubscript{n} converges to

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T
\end{align*}

as $n \to \infty$.

\textbf{(b)} What is the value of the inner (dot) product
$\langle \mathbf{x}_\infty, A\mathbf{x}_\infty\rangle$?
statement_raw:
Suppose that ''A'' is a symmetric 4x4 matrix with eigenvalues 0, 1, 4, 5. Define a sequence of vectors <math>\mathbf{x}_n \in \mathbb{R}^4</math> by choosing '''x'''<sub>0</sub> at random, and then settings

:<math> \begin{align}
\mathbf{y}_n &= (A-3I)^{-1}\mathbf{x}_{n-1} \\
\mathbf{x}_n &= \mathbf{y}_n/\|\mathbf{y}_{n}\|
\end{align} </math>

for ''n = 1, 2, ...''. You then observe that '''x'''<sub>n</sub> converges to

:<math>
\mathbf{x}_\infty = [1/2, 1/2, 1/2, 1/2]^T
</math>

as <math> n \to \infty</math>.

'''(b)''' What is the value of the inner (dot) product <math>\langle \mathbf{x}_\infty, A\mathbf{x}_\infty\rangle</math>?
